=Copyright infringement of software= The '''[[copyright infringement]] of [[software]]''' (often referred to as '''software piracy''') refers to several practices which involve the unauthorized copying of computer software. Copyright infringement of this kind varies globally<ref>http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/cri_sof_pir_rat-crime-software-piracy-rate</ref>. Most countries have copyright laws which apply to software, but the degree of enforcement varies.
It is a copyright violation to download, upload or otherwise distribute copyrighted material through the internet without authorization. == Existing and proposed laws == {{Main|Copyright infringement|History of copyright law|Digital Millennium Copyright Act|Protect IP Act|Stop Online Piracy Act|Software_copyright}}
[[File:Pro piracy demonstration.jpg|thumb|Demonstration in [[Sweden]] in support of software piracy, [[2006]].]] [[File:The Pirate Bay logo.svg|right|thumb|[[The Pirate Bay]] logo, a retaliation to the stereotypical image of software piracy]]
[[List of countries' copyright length|Most countries]] extend copyright protections to software. Even the oldest legacy computer systems used [[2011|today]] will not have their [[list of countries' copyright length|copyright expire]] until 2030. In the United States, copyright term has been extended many times over<ref>http://copyright.gov/circs/circ1a.html</ref> from the original term of 14 years with a single renewal allowance of 14 years, to the current term of the life of the author plus 70 years. If the work was produced under [[corporate authorship]] it may last 120 years after creation or 95 years after publication, whichever is less.
Punishment of copyright infringement varies case-by-case across countries. Convictions may include jail time and/or severe fines for each instance of copyright infringement. In the United States, willful copyright infringement carries a maximum penalty of $150,000 per instance.<ref>http://copyright.gov/title17/92chap5.html</ref>.
Proposed laws such as the [[Stop Online Piracy Act]] broaden the definition of "willful infringement", and introduce felony charges for unauthorized [[Main|media streaming]]. These bills are aimed towards defeating websites that carry or contain links to infringing content, but have raised concerns about domestic abuse and internet censorship.
Title I of the [[United States|US]] [[DMCA]], the [[WIPO Copyright and Performances and Phonograms Treaties Implementation Act]] has provisions that prevent persons from "circumvent[ing] a technological measure that effectively controls access to a work". Thus if a software manufacturer has some kind of software, [[dongle]] or password access device installed in the software any attempt to bypass such a [[copy protection]] scheme may be [[cause of action|actionable]] — though the US Copyright Office is currently reviewing anticircumvention rulemaking under DMCA — anticircumvention exemptions that have been in place under the DMCA include those in software designed to filter websites that are generally seen to be inefficient (child safety and public library website filtering software) and the circumvention of copy protection mechanisms that have malfunctioned, have caused the software to become inoperable or which are no longer supported by their manufacturers.
==Limitations== Copyright does not protect the technical form nor R&D<ref>http://www.ladas.com/Patents/Computer/SoftwareAndCopyright/Softwa06.html#fn30</ref> of an original work. [[Copyright]] contains a [[Substantial similarity]] requirement to determine whether the work falls under the [[Fair use]] clause.
Evaluation of alleged software copyright infringement in a court of law may be non-trivial; if an original work is alleged to have been modified, then tests such as the [[Abstraction-Filtration-Comparison test]] (AFC Test)<ref>http://www.ifosslr.org/ifosslr/article/download/30/54</ref><ref>http://www.linux.com/archive/feature/113252</ref> are used to detect infringement. The time and costs required to apply this test naturally vary based on the size and complexity of the copyrighted material. Furthermore, there is no standard or universally accepted test; some courts have rejected the AFC Test it in favor of narrower testing criteria.
== Impact of copyright infringement == === Claims of economic harm === The [[Business Software Alliance|BSA]] and [[International Data Corporation|IDC]] claim that losses from software piracy in 2009 have exceeded $51 billion.<ref>[http://www.pcworld.com/article/196110/bsa_piracy_study_quantifying_piracy_data_easier_than_we_thought.html BSA Piracy Study: Quantifying Piracy Data Easier Than We Thought]</ref>
In addition, it has been claimed that reducing piracy rates would provide significant economical benefits: {{quote|Lowering software piracy by just 10 percentage points during the next four years would create nearly 500,000 new jobs and pump $140 billion into ailing economies.| John Gantz, chief research officer at IDC<ref>[http://www.bsa.org/country/News%20and%20Events/News%20Archives/global/05112010-globalpiracystudy.aspx BSA Reports $51 Billion Worth of Software Theft in 2009]</ref>}}
According to a BSA/IDC studies, the highest piracy rate comes from Armenia, with piracy rate of 93%. China and India are at No. 17 and No. 41 respectively , with 82% and 69% of recorded Software Piracy rates.<ref>[http://portal.bsa.org/idcglobalstudy2007/studies/2007_global_piracy_study.pdf Fifth Annual BSA and IDC Global Software Piracy Study]</ref> The lowest piracy rate, according to survey, is observed in USA, at 20%.
However, the methodology of these studies have been [[Business_Software_Alliance#BSA_annual_software_piracy_study|heavily criticized]]. Estimated losses have been found to be heavily exaggerated<ref>http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20100511/1516059386.shtml</ref> or outright fabricated<ref>http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20090527/1125035034.shtml</ref>. In addition to misrepresenting data, the BSA and other like associations have been found to rely on the perpetuation of myths, tropes, and moral pedagogy<ref>http://nms.sagepub.com/content/10/4/605.short</ref> in lieu of data.
=== Claims of economic advantage === Jeff Raikes, a [[Microsoft]] executive, stated that "If they're going to pirate somebody, we want it to be us rather than somebody else." He also added <ref>http://arstechnica.com/journals/microsoft.ars/2007/03/12/microsoft-executive-pirating-software-choose-microsoft</ref> that "We understand that in the long run the fundamental asset is the installed base of people who are using our products. What you hope to do over time is convert them to licensing the software." In a different case, Microsoft has admitted that piracy of its Windows operating system has helped give it huge market share in China that will boost its revenues when these users "go legit." Bill Gates said, "It's easier for our software to compete with [[Linux]] when there's piracy than when there's not."<ref>{{Cite journal|pages=23|title=Piracy: Look for the Silver Lining|author=The Economist|edition=July 19th-25th, 2008|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> He has also said in reference to China: {{quote|As long as they are going to steal it, we want them to steal ours. They'll get sort of addicted, and then we'll somehow figure out how to collect sometime in the next decade.|[[Bill Gates]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1023-212942.html|title=Gates, Buffett a bit bearish|date=July 2, 1998|publisher=[[CNET]]}}</ref>}} In this way, copyright infringement acts as a market penetration tool<ref>http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0883902606000899</ref> to set standards and create dependency on the software.
Software copyright holders have found that in many conditions they see higher profits because of piracy<ref>http://www.wiwi.uni-duesseldorf.de/lehrstuehle/dice/Institut/Professoren/Dokumente/rasch_wenzel_2011b.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0883902606000899</ref>. Authors that have distributed their work online with [[open licensing]] universally agreed that they achieved much greater success, profit, and impact from their work because of piracy<ref>http://www.springerlink.com/content/6t6388667v317711/</ref>.
=== Developing countries === Most commercially exploited proprietary software is developed in the [[United States]] and [[Europe]]{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}. Critics in developing countries see this as an indirect technology transfer tax on their country, preventing technological advancement. This is the leading reason developing countries refuse to accept or respect copyright laws. This idea is often applied to [[patent]] laws as well. [[Traian BÄsescu]], the president of [[Romania]], stated that "piracy helped the young generation discover computers. It set off the development of the IT industry in Romania."<ref>Nathan Davis. [http://apcmag.com/5254/thanks_for_letting_us_pirate Thanks for letting us pirate]. 5 February 2007.</ref>
The debate about software piracy acceptance in developing countries still continues. In 2011, the [[Business Software Alliance]] announces that 83 percent of software deployed on PCs in [[Africa]] has been pirated (excluding [[South Africa]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://torrentfreak.com/software-piracy-110822/ |title=Software Piracy (Infographic) |date=August 22, 2011}}</ref>
=== Copyright and free software === Certain [[Free software|free software]] licenses (most notably [[GPL]]) substantially rely on existing copyright law. It is not possible to enforce GPL other than within the framework of existing copyright law.<ref>[http://www.brainhandles.com/techno-thoughts/technology-life/should-copyright-be-abolished Should copyright be abolished]</ref><ref>[http://www.groklaw.net/articlebasic.php?story=20041028000105896 The Sustainable GPL]</ref> As GPL being strongly associated with word [[Copyleft]], there is certain confusion about GPL and copyright, but despite somewhat confusing wording, ''copyleft'' is indeed one (unprivative) of copyright licensing schemas.
